citation.article-title: Desulfovibrio putealis sp. nov., a novel sulfate-reducing bacterium isolated from a deep subsurface aquifer
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Desulfovibrio putealis sp. nov.
Desulfovibrio putealis (pu.te.a′lis. L. adj. putealis from a well).
Motile by means of a single polar flagellum.
Optimum growth occurs at 30 °C and pH 7·0.
Grows in 0–6 g NaCl l−1, with optimum growth at 1 g NaCl l−1.
Able to use sulfate, sulfite and thiosulfate, with production of sulfide.
Nitrate is not used as an electron acceptor.
Substrates that are oxidized by anaerobic respiration of a sulfate compound are H2, lactate, pyruvate, malate, fumarate, ethanol, butanol and glycine.
H2 is only utilized in the presence of acetate.
Pyruvate, fumarate and malate are fermented.
Acetate, butyrate, benzoate, succinate, citrate, methanol, glucose, fructose, alanine, glutamate, aspartate, formate, toluene and propanol are not utilized.
The type strain is B7-43T (=DSM 16056T=ATCC BAA-905T), which was isolated from a water-producing well in France.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 57·8 mol%.
